title: 115_s2291
content:
Permanent modification of individual rate brackets for married individuals filing joint returns and surviving spouses under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The tax rates for different income brackets under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 are as follows:
- Not over $19,050: 10% of taxable income
- Over $19,050 but not over $77,400: $1,905 plus 12% of the excess over $19,050
- Over $77,400 but not over $165,000: $8,907 plus 22% of the excess over $77,400
- Over $165,000 but not over $315,000: $28,179 plus 24% of the excess over $165,000
- Over $315,000 but not over $400,000: $64,179 plus 32% of the excess over $315,000
- Over $400,000 but not over $600,000: $91,379 plus 35% of the excess over $400,000
- Over $600,000: $161,379 plus 37% of the excess over $600,000. The table in subsection (b) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended for Heads of Households. The tax rates for taxable income for Heads of Households are as follows:
- Not over $13,600: 10% of taxable income
- Over $13,600 but not over $51,800: $1,360 plus 12% of the excess
- Over $51,800 but not over $82,500: $5,944 plus 22% of the excess
- Over $82,500 but not over $157,500: $12,698 plus 24% of the excess
- Over $157,500 but not over $200,000: $30,698 plus 32% of the excess
- Over $200,000 but not over $500,000: $44,298 plus 35% of the excess
- Over $500,000: $149,298 plus 37% of the excess. The table in subsection (c) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended for unmarried individuals other than surviving spouses and heads of households. The tax rates for different income brackets are as follows:
- Not over $9,525: 10% of taxable income
- Over $9,525 but not over $38,700: $952.50 plus 12% of the excess
- Over $38,700 but not over $82,500: $4,453.50 plus 22% of the excess
- Over $82,500 but not over $157,500: $14,089.50 plus 24% of the excess
- Over $157,500 but not over $200,000: $32,089.50 plus 32% of the excess
- Over $200,000 but not over $500,000: $45,689.50 plus 35% of the excess
- Over $500,000: $150,689.50 plus 37% of the excess. The tax rates for different income brackets are specified in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, with amendments for married individuals filing separate returns. The tax rates for different income brackets are specified in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, with amendments for married individuals filing separate returns. If taxable income is not over $9,525, the tax is 10% of taxable income. For income over $9,525 but not over $38,700, the tax is $952.50 plus 12% of the excess. The tax rates increase progressively for higher income levels. The tax rates for estates and trusts under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 have been amended. The new table shows that for taxable income not over $2,550, the tax is 10% of taxable income. For income over $2,550 but not over $9,150, the tax is $255 plus 24% of the excess. For income over $9,150 but not over $12,500, the tax is $1,839 plus 35% of the excess. For income over $12,500, the tax is $3,011.50 plus 37% of the excess. (f) Adjustment for Inflation.--Section 1 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to update various provisions, including changing the year reference from 1993 to 2018, adjusting income thresholds, and modifying filing status descriptions. Additionally, paragraph (8) is removed. Subsection (g) is also amended to include special rules for certain children with unearned income. Subsection (g) of section 1 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to restructure paragraphs and introduce new provisions for determining tax on children. The tax on children is determined with modifications for different tax brackets, ensuring that their taxable income is not more than the sum of their earned income and the minimum taxable income for the respective bracket. The tax on children is determined based on their earned income and the minimum taxable income for the applicable tax bracket, ensuring it does not exceed certain limits. The tax on children is calculated based on their earned taxable income, which is the sum of their taxable income and certain additional amounts specified in subsections (h)(12)(A)(iv) and (h)(12)(B)(iv) for the taxable year. The tax on children is calculated based on their earned taxable income, which is the sum of their taxable income and certain additional amounts specified in subsections (h)(12)(A)(iv) and (h)(12)(B)(iv) for the taxable year. Amendments are made to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 regarding the reduction of taxable income for children and adjustments to capital gains brackets. The maximum zero rate amount for different filing statuses is defined in subsection (h)(12)(A) as $77,200 for joint returns or surviving spouses, $51,700 for heads of household, and half of the joint return amount for other individuals. The maximum 15-percent rate amount for different filing statuses is $479,000 for joint returns or surviving spouses, $452,400 for heads of household, $425,800 for other individuals, and $12,700 for estates or trusts. The dollar amounts for different filing statuses are subject to inflation adjustments starting in 2018. Increases will be based on the cost-of-living adjustment for the calendar year, rounded to the nearest multiple of $50. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to change tax rates, with adjustments to the dollar amounts for filing statuses based on inflation starting in 2018. The amendments will apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2018.
